title: Sydney Tomsick
text:
Sydney Tomsick is a 3rd year Statistics and Data Science major at UCLA with a minor in Digital Humanities. She is passionate about deriving valuable insights through data, and presenting her findings in creative and innovative ways. She also enjoys web design and user experience research. Outside of academic pursuits, Sydney loves to dance and is one of the directors of Synthesis Dance Theater, a dance club at UCLA.

Sydney is a data journalist for The Stack, a branch of the Daily Bruin. She writes articles about various topics on campus centered around data insights and visualizations. Here is an article she wrote about startups at UCLA.

title: Exploring Female Representation in MoMA
text:
My team and I created a website discussing the lack of female representation in art museums. We used this dataset created by the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) to make visualizations showing how female artist representation has changed in MoMA overtime both in the US and globally. Using our research, we discussed potential connections between changes in gender representation in MoMA and feminist movements taking place at the same time.

Our Research Questions

How did waves of feminism and American social movements of the mid-1900s affect the representation of American female artists in the MoMA collection? 
Beyond the U.S., how did global feminist movements relate to the ethnic diversity of female artists in the MoMA collection?



My Responsibilities
My main responsibility in this project was web design through WordPress. I also helped clean the data and create data visualizations.

title: Exploring Female Representation in MoMA
text:
My team and I created a website discussing the lack of female representation in art museums. We used this dataset created by the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) to make visualizations showing how female artist representation has changed in MoMA overtime both in the US and globally. Using our research, we discussed potential connections between changes in gender representation in MoMA and feminist movements taking place at the same time.

Our Research Questions

How did waves of feminism and American social movements of the mid-1900s affect the representation of American female artists in the MoMA collection? 
Beyond the U.S., how did global feminist movements relate to the ethnic diversity of female artists in the MoMA collection?



My Role
My main responsibility in this project was web design through WordPress. I also helped clean the data and create data visualizations.

title: A Clinical Study: The Effect of Caffeine and Exercise on Attention
text:
Methods
Using a 2-way factorial design with interactions, I studied whether caffeine intake and exercise duration significantly impact attention span.
There were 9 experimental groups in total. The 2 factors each had 3 levels:

Caffeine intake: Green Tea (250mL), Coffee (250mL), Coffee (500mL)
Running distance: 100m, 1km, 5km

I used ANOVA to reveal whether caffeine intake, running distance, or their interaction had a statistically significant effect on attention span. I used Tukey’s test to revel whether any individual group differed significantly from the others.

title: Kaggle Competition: Predicting Obesity Status
text:
My team and I were provided with training and testing datasets containing 29 predictors of obesity status capturing aspects such as dietary habits, physical activity, water consumption, and family medical history. The outcome variable “obesity status” classified individuals as either “Obese” or “Not Obese”.
We were tasked with predicting obesity status for the testing dataset and determining the most influential predictors. This is our final report.

Methods
First, we imputed the data using random forests to fill in missing values. Then, we tried multiple models to predict obesity status such as logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests. Our random forests model with 500 trees performed best, with a testing prediction accuracy of 99.943%.
We then found the most influential predictors using correlation analysis (point-biserial and Cramer’s V correlation) and variable importance from the random forest model.
